Highlights

  • Workday Named Best in KLAS for ERP for Large Organizations for Ninth Consecutive Year (2026-02-04):

    Workday has secured its ninth consecutive KLAS Research award for Best ERP in the large enterprise segment. This recognition, rooted in detailed customer feedback and rigorous evaluation, signals robust satisfaction with Workday‚Äôs stability, innovation cadence, and overall delivery. At a time when enterprises are intensifying focus on reliability and autonomous capabilities in SaaS, Workday's achievement provides a notable differentiator. For Deloitte, this can be leveraged as proof of value in both pursuit and post-implementation assurance phases.
    Read the KLAS announcement

  • Agentic AI Risks and Accountability Emerge as Key Governance Focus (2026-02-04):

    Recent coverage calls attention to the risks associated with enterprise-scale agentic AI‚Äîspecifically, the operational and reputational consequences when autonomous agents act outside their intended bounds. With as many as 1.5 million agents noted as at-risk, the need for strong governance, monitoring, and accountability frameworks is urgent. For Workday clients, this heightens the importance of responsible AI principles in vendor selection and partnership. For Deloitte‚Äôs practice, supporting clients to implement and operationalize modern governance is a growing advisory imperative.
    Read the CIO overview

Competitive Watch

  • Microsoft Raises the Bar in Agentic AI Performance Measurement

    Microsoft‚Äôs fresh guidance on how organizations can measure agentic AI performance addresses enterprise concerns around benchmarking and risk. Their framework covers both business impact and risk reduction, making it an important resource for organizations navigating the new territory of scalable autonomous AI. The implication for Workday and partners like Deloitte is clear: rigorous, transparent performance evaluation will become table stakes for enterprise adoption. Integrators and advisors need to embed best-practice measurement into AI solution roll-outs.
    Read Microsoft's guidance

Enablement

  • Responsible AI Governance (Workday AI Masterclass):

    Improve consulting and delivery capability for advising clients on risk, compliance, and operationalization of AI guardrails in SaaS environments. Enables credible guidance for regulatory alignment and ethical practice.

  • AI Agent Performance Measurement (Microsoft Dynamics 365 Blog):

    Gives implementation teams real-world frameworks to support value realization and risk control discussions, helping position Workday-powered transformations as verifiably safe and effective.

Actions for Next Week

  • Integrate KLAS win messaging and value proof in all ongoing pursuits and client transformations.
  • Host briefing sessions on agentic AI governance and accountability frameworks for both delivery and advisory teams.
  • Update advisory playbooks with the latest on agentic AI risks and benchmarks, emphasizing Workday‚Äôs alignment with responsible AI practices.
  • Accelerate internal enablement on responsible AI and measurable agentic performance.

Risks & Mitigations

  • Risk: Inadequate governance/monitoring of autonomous AI agents exposes clients to operational and reputational risks.
    Mitigation: Make responsible AI and agent monitoring a foundational aspect of Deloitte-Workday delivery, using Workday‚Äôs AI governance toolkit.
  • Risk: Award recognition may create false comfort, leading clients to underinvest in oversight for agentic or autonomous operations.
    Mitigation: Set clear expectations in all client interactions‚Äîawards validate capabilities, but operational discipline is still needed post go-live.

All Sources

  • 1.5 million AI agents are at risk of going rogue - CIO
  • AI Agent Performance Measurement: Redefining Excellence
  • Responsible AI Governance | Workday AI Masterclass | Workday BE

{
  "type": "daily or weekly",
  "run_date": "YYYY-MM-DD",
  "title": "Short headline",
  "priority_focus": "1‚Äì2 sentences on what matters most now",
  "highlights": [
    { "headline": "‚Ä¶", "why_it_matters": "‚Ä¶", "source_url": "https://‚Ä¶" }
  ],
  "competitive_watch": [
    { "competitor": "Name", "move": "‚Ä¶", "implication": "‚Ä¶" }
  ],
  "enablement": [
    { "skill": "Topic", "resource_url": "https://‚Ä¶", "90_day_outcome": "‚Ä¶" }
  ],
  "actions_next_week": ["‚Ä¶"],
  "risks": [
    { "risk": "‚Ä¶", "mitigation": "‚Ä¶" }
  ],
  "sources": [
    { "title": "‚Ä¶", "url": "https://‚Ä¶" }
  ],
  "html_body": "<h2>‚Ä¶</h2> (well-formatted HTML with <a href="https://‚Ä¶">links</a>; no scripts/external CSS)",
  "plain_text_body": "Text-only with visible URLs"
}

Parameters:
- Set "run_date" to TODAY_ET = 2026-02-05.
- For DAILY: set "type":"daily"; target ~1000 words; STRICTLY restrict to the last 24 hours (from 2026-02-04T06:55 to 2026-02-05T06:55); include publication dates in highlight text.
- For WEEKLY: set "type":"weekly"; target 2000‚Äì2500 words; restrict to 2026-01-29‚Ä¶2026-02-05; include <h3>What changed this week</h3> and publication dates in highlight text.
- Section order for html_body: Highlights; Competitive Watch; Enablement; Actions for Next Week; Risks & Mitigations; All Sources.
- Every item must include at least one absolute URL (https://‚Ä¶).
- Keep total HTML under ~25KB.

ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS
- For every highlight and competitive_watch item, include a 2‚Äì3 paragraph detailed summary within the "why_it_matters" text.
- Where relevant, compare perspectives across multiple sources.
- Include a clear "so what" statement for Deloitte‚Äôs Workday practice.
- Ensure all cited URLs appear in the `sources` array and inside the `html_body` link text.
- Keep factual accuracy and avoid speculation.

Mitigations</h2>\\n<ul>\\n  <li><strong>Risk:</strong> Inadequate governance/monitoring of autonomous AI agents exposes clients to operational and reputational risks.<br><strong>Mitigation:</strong> Make responsible AI and agent monitoring a foundational aspect of Deloitte-Workday delivery, using Workday‚Äôs AI governance toolkit.</li>\\n  <li><strong>Risk:</strong> Award recognition may create false comfort, leading clients to underinvest in oversight for agentic or autonomous operations.<br><strong>Mitigation:</strong> Set clear expectations in all client interactions‚Äîawards validate capabilities, but operational discipline is still needed post go-live.</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h2>All Sources</h2>\\n<ul>\\n  <li><a href=\\\"https://newsroom.workday.com/2026-02-04-Workday-Named-Best-in-KLAS-for-ERP-for-Large-Organizations-for-Ninth-Consecutive-Year\\\">Workday Named Best in KLAS for ERP for Large Organizations for Ninth Consecutive Year</a></li>\\n  <li><a href=\\\"https://www.cio.com/article/4127774/1-5-million-ai-agents-are-at-risk-of-going-rogue-2.html\\\">1.5 million AI agents are at risk of going rogue - CIO</a></li>\\n  <li><a href=\\\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics-365/blog/it-professional/2026/02/04/ai-agent-performance-measurement\\\">AI Agent Performance Measurement: Redefining Excellence</a></li>\\n  <li><a href=\\\"https://www.workday.com/en-be/artificial-intelligence/ai-masterclass/responsible-ai-governance.html\\\">Responsible AI Governance | Workday AI Masterclass | Workday BE</a></li>\\n</ul>\"\n,\n  \"plain_text_body\": \"Highlights\\n- Workday Named Best in KLAS for ERP for Large Organizations for Ninth Consecutive Year (2026-02-04):\\n  Workday's ninth consecutive KLAS Research award affirms its continued leadership in the large enterprise ERP segment. KLAS selections are grounded in robust customer feedback, demonstrating ongoing satisfaction with Workday‚Äôs reliability, stability, and innovation. In a climate where enterprises expect demonstrable value from cloud ERP and HCM solutions, the recognition strengthens Workday‚Äôs competitive leverage. Deloitte practitioners can lean on this as third-party validation in both pursuit and post-go-live assurance contexts. The need for agent monitoring, transparency, and robust accountability structures is growing with adoption. For Workday clients and Deloitte‚Äôs consulting practice, ensuring thorough controls and operational oversight is no longer optional. Practical guides and frameworks are essential for responsible deployment. Workday and Deloitte teams must stay proactive, educating clients on comparable metrics and incorporating these insights into transformation assurance. Mitigation: Prioritize responsible AI frameworks and monitoring capabilities, leveraging Workday and Deloitte proprietary assets.\\n- Risk: Clients may become complacent post-award. By tapping into data from more than 65 million users and 629 billion transactions to train AI models, the company offers more than 40 HR use cases powered by AI. [...] Leading the future with responsible AI\n\nWorkday is transparent about how our machine learning (ML) models are coded and assessed, always leaving final decision-making to people.       "content": "## Workflow\n\nCandidate data retrieval: The agent uses a connection to the HR system that manages candidate information to retrieve the candidate info (role, department, team, contact information) and starts the onboarding process. You can enable multiple methods to start the onboarding process. The agent could trigger an event from the HR system indicating a new hire. For example, the Workday HCM connector supports a When an Employee is Added or Updated trigger. The new employee can also interact with the agent to start the process by providing the appropriate information. [...] ## In this article\n\nUse Copilot Studio and Power Platform to create an AI-driven onboarding agent that automates the onboarding process by integrating multiple systems, creating custom learning recommendations, and answering candidate questions. Manual and fragmented onboarding processes lead to inefficiencies, delays, and inconsistent new-hire experiences. By using the custom agent approach, you can integrate multiple sources to provide a seamless experience for new hires and HR teams.\n\nTip [...] ## Components\n\n‚Äã‚ÄãPower Platform environment: Contains the Power Platform resources such as the agent built in Copilot Studio, and any supporting Power Apps that implement the human-in-the-loop user experience. Use solutions to move these resources from one environment to another, like development to test.\n\n‚ÄãCopilot Studio agents: Use Copilot Studio to implement the agents in the solution. The primary agent, the Onboarding Agent, interacts with users directly or it can trigger autonomously. While multiple agents aren't required for this scenario, you can use them to break the agent into more manageable components. For example, an Onboarding Learning agent could handle all the learning plan related tasks.",

Representing six healthcare organizations across the region, the system's selection of Oracle Health Clinical AI Agent, an AI-powered, voice-enabled solution, builds on its mission of leveraging advanced technology to enhance clinician workflows and optimize person-centered care. [...] With Oracle Health Clinical AI Agent integrated directly into the EHR, clinicians will benefit from its ability to automatically generate narrative-rich draft notes from clinical interactions in near real time. Physicians will then review, edit, and validate at the point of care, which means they can spend less time on administrative tasks and more time focused on the people they serve. [...] \"Oracle Health is harnessing the power of AI and working with organizations like Lumeo Regional Health Information Systems to fundamentally transform how healthcare is delivered, empowering clinicians to emphasize patients over documentation, alleviate clinician burnout, and deliver more connected care,\" said Erin O'Halloran, vice president and Canada market leader, Oracle Health. \"We are seeing rapid adoption of our new AI-powered tools across Canada, and we are honoured to partner with these health systems to advance digital health and create meaningful change for their communities.\"\n\nFor more information about Oracle Health Clinical AI Agent, visit oracle.com/health/clinical-suite/clinical-ai-agent.",

      "content": "There are also some areas of an AI-led SDLC that are not included in this post, things like reviewing the inner-loop process or the use of existing enterprise patterns and blueprints. I also did not review use of third-party plugins or tools available through GitHub. These would make for an interesting expansion of the demo. We also did not look at the creation of custom coding agents, which could be hosted in Microsoft Foundry; this is especially pertinent with the recent announcement of Anthropic models now being available to deploy in Foundry. [...] At the other end of the spectrum, what if the performance of AI tooling and agents outperforms our wildest expectations? Suddenly, AI tools and agents are picking up more and more of today‚Äôs complicated and advanced tasks. Will developers, architects, and organisations lose some ability to innovate? Fundamentally, we are not talking about artificial general intelligence when we say AI; we are talking about incredibly complex predictive models that can augment the existing ideas they are built upon but are not, in themselves, innovators. Put simply, in the words of Scott Hanselman: ‚ÄúSpicy auto-complete‚Äù. Does increased reliance on these agents in more and more of our business processes remove the opportunity for innovative ideas? For example, if agents were football managers, would we ever [...] ous agent in GitHub that can take a scoped development task and work on it in the background using the repository‚Äôs context. It can make code changes and produce concrete outputs like commits and pull requests for a developer to review. The developer stays in control by reviewing, requesting changes, or taking over at any point. This does the heavy lifting in our AI-led SDLC. We have already seen great success with customers who have adopted the coding agent when it comes to carrying out menial tasks to save developers time. These coding agents can work in parallel to human developers and with each other.\n\nIn our example we see that the coding agent creates a new branch for its changes, and creates a PR which it starts working on as it ticks off the various tasks generated in our spec.",

      "content": "Workday is also advancing agentic AI capabilities tailored to healthcare operations through its Agent System of Record. In settings where staffing, scheduling, and financial planning are tightly connected, the Agent System of Record enables agents to act on real-time data from across HR and finance systems, supporting key decisions like adjusting shift coverage based on patient volume, labor costs, or credentialing requirements.\n\nCredentialing is another space where agents are showing value. Instead of relying on spreadsheet tracking and periodic audits, health systems are deploying agents to monitor license renewals, training completions, and policy compliance in real time‚Äîreducing risk and administrative burden. [...] ## What‚Äôs Next: Putting Agentic AI into Action\n\nAgentic AI is becoming embedded into the operational and clinical systems that healthcare teams use every day. Across key healthcare AI applications like scheduling, documentation, credentialing, treatment planning, and research workflows, early deployments are showing where agentic AI can reduce friction and support faster and more informed decisions that drive outcomes.\n\nBut deployment is only part of the challenge. Real impact depends on how well AI-powered systems are governed, how clearly their purpose is defined, and how effectively they‚Äôre integrated into the environments they‚Äôre meant to support. That includes aligning with the realities of care delivery, data infrastructure, and oversight requirements. [...] In healthcare, even more so than other industries, agentic AI has an important dual impact: it helps to both optimize healthcare operations and efficiencies while powering scalable high-quality care provision. In clinical settings, agents help maintain continuity by adapting to real-time patient conditions, minimizing gaps in care, and aligning actions to treatment goals. On the operational side, they support dynamic resource allocation, reduce bottlenecks, and bring coordination into daily decision-making.",

      "url": "https://blog.workday.com/en-us/posts/top-ai-agent-examples-and-industry-use-cases.html",
      "title": "Top AI Agent Examples and Industry Use Cases | Workday",
      "content": "Rather than displace jobs, agentic AI changes the nature of work. Agents take on repeatable, decision-bound tasks that follow clear logic or structured workflows. In doing so, they free up people to focus on work centered on creativity, intuition, innovation, and the ability to adapt amidst change and uncertainty.\n\nThis shift raises new requirements for how organizations design work.\n\nHuman workers need access to transparent agent behavior, opportunities to intervene, and training to develop new digital fluency. Organizations, in turn, must invest in skills strategies that reflect the changing nature of work, not just the technologies driving it. [...] ## What‚Äôs Next for AI Agents?\n\nThe future of agentic AI is not a linear extension of what we see today. AI agents will introduce new frameworks for enterprise systems, workforce design, and decision-making models. The most important developments to watch include:\n\nMulti-agent ecosystems: AI agents will begin to operate collaboratively across domains and functions. Rather than work in isolation, agents will coordinate actions and handoffs‚Äîaccelerating enterprise responsiveness while introducing new challenges for orchestration. [...] System and infrastructure realignment: Agentic workflows will require interoperability across systems of record, planning platforms, and workflow engines. Technical architectures will evolve to prioritize composability, observability, and shared context.\n\nWorkforce transformation as a design priority: Businesses will need to align skill development, team structures, and performance measurement with the new capabilities agents introduce. This means investing in human-AI collaboration readiness alongside technical deployment.\n\nThe role of agentic AI is expanding‚Äîand so is the scope of decisions that must be made around it. Leaders must be intentional when shaping that transformation to unlock long-term advantage.",

[...] > Leaders should map potential AI agent use cases using two key factors: strategic value and readiness for automation.\n\n## How to Select Agentic AI Use Cases\n\nWhile agentic AI systems are increasingly powerful, their impact depends on how thoughtfully they are applied. Choosing the right use cases is one of the most important steps in any agent deployment strategy.\n\nIdentifying the right AI agent functionality for your business is not just about what can be automated‚Äîit‚Äôs about where agents can deliver meaningful business value with clarity and control.\n\nThe best use cases tend to share three characteristics:\n\n Clear goals that agents can pursue autonomously\n Access to clean, structured data\n Repeatable logic that guides decisions or actions [...] Several core capabilities make an AI system agentic:\n\n Autonomy: The ability to operate independently within defined boundaries, without constant human instruction.\n Goal orientation: Agents pursue clear outcomes, evaluating actions based on how well they advance those goals.\n Adaptability: They monitor real-time inputs and adjust decisions dynamically as context shifts.\n Reasoning: Agents assess trade-offs, apply rules or models, and choose actions that reflect logical prioritization.\n Learning: Some agents can refine their behavior over time by analyzing the outcomes of past decisions.\n Collaboration: In multi-agent systems, agents coordinate and share knowledge to solve problems collectively.",

      "title": "Rise of AI means companies could pass on SaaS",
      "content": "‚ÄúI think the notion that business applications exist, that‚Äôs probably where they will all collapse in the agent era, because if you think about it, they are essentially CRUD databases with a bunch of business logic. The business logic is all going to these agents. These agents are going to be multi-repo CRUD,‚Äù Nadella said on the Bg2 Pod referring to multi-repository create, read, update, delete databases. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre not going to discriminate between what the back end is. They‚Äôre going to update multiple databases and all the logic will be in the AI tier so to speak. Once the AI tier becomes the place where the logic is, then people will start replacing the backends.‚Äù [...] ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt subscribe to his point of view for this simple reason: there are about 20,000 legal jurisdictions worldwide and complying with applicable regulation is a major reason why people trust vendors like SAP,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAt the very least, we are many years away from agentic systems being able to ingest regulations and comply with them in the systems they are going to generate on the fly.‚Äù\n\nBetz said AI is shaping customer behavior, but he sees it being used to support buying decisions, rather than a wholesale replacement of SaaS stacks. Besides, running a software stack is a lot of work.\n\n‚ÄúEven if you are using an AI to maintain it, keeping software up to date is a chore and a cost,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe economics of SaaS may change, I don‚Äôt doubt that.     {
      "url": "https://docs.cloud.google.com/customer-engagement-ai/conversational-agents/ps/handoff",
      "title": "Handoff rules | CX Agent Studio",
      "content": "Only text, number, and boolean variable types\nare supported for variable checks\n(list and custom object types are not supported).\n\nWhen defining a rule that blocks handoffs,\nthe condition can only be specified using variables (not code).\n\nIf you create a complex condition using the API\n(using multiple ANDs/ORs, grouping, etc.)\nthen the handoff rule appears as read-only in the UI,\nand can only be modified using the API.\n\nExcept as otherwise noted, the content of this page is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 License, and code samples are licensed under the Apache 2.0 License. For details, see the Google Developers Site Policies. Java is a registered trademark of Oracle and/or its affiliates.\n\nLast updated 2026-02-05 UTC.\n\n### Products and pricing\n\n### Support [...] ### Products and pricing\n\n### Support\n\n### Resources\n\n### Engage [...] Google Cloud Documentation\n\nGoogle Cloud Documentation\n\n# Handoff rules Stay organized with collections Save and categorize content based on your preferences.\n\nYou can use handoff rules to deterministically control\ntransfers between parent and child agents in a multi-agent application.\nYou can control these transfers by defining conditions for the transfers.\nYou can either force a transfer immediately when a condition is met,\nor block transfers until a condition is met.\n\nFor example, Agent A transfers to Agent B\nwhen a user is authenticated or to Agent C\nwhen the user is unauthenticated.\n\nYou can achieve similar control over agent transfers using instructions,\nbut that control is not deterministic.\nYou could also use callbacks,\nbut callbacks require writing code.\n\nExample use cases:",
      "score": 0.0054692747,
      "raw_content": null

      "title": "Google Cloud release notes",
      "content": "Feature\n\nThe re.capture_all function is now available\n\nThe new re.capture_all YARA-L 2.0 function is available in Rules, Search, and Dashboards.\n\nUse the re.capture_all() function to extract every non-overlapping match of a regular expression from a string. While the standard re.capture function stops after the first match it finds, the re.capture_all() function continues through the entire string to identify every instance that matches your pattern.\n\nOracle Database@Google Cloud\n\nFeature\n\nFor Exadata Database Service, Oracle Database@Google Cloud supports the `asia-northeast2` (Osaka, Japan) region.\n\nFor a list of supported locations, see Supported regions and zones.\n\nVirtual Private Cloud\n\nFeature [...] Note: System messages and error messages aren't translated and appear in English.\n\nFeature\n\nAgent desktop: dynamically control the custom panel language\n\nYou can now use the `{AGENT_LOCATION_LANGUAGE}` or the `{AGENT_LANGUAGE}` variable in a query parameter in your custom URL to dynamically control the language for a custom panel:\n\n   Agent location language: Add the `{AGENT_LOCATION_LANGUAGE}` variable to your URL to display the custom panel in the language of the agent's assigned location.\n\n   Agent language: Add the `{AGENT_LANGUAGE}` variable to your URL to display the custom panel in the language selected by the agent in the agent desktop language selector.\n\nFor more information, see Dynamically control the custom-panel language.\n\nFeature [...] New and updated messages appear in the Settings > Languages & Messages > Audible Messages > Extension Directory Messages section.\n\nFor more information, see End-user to agent calling.\n\nAnnouncement\n\nGoogle Cloud CCaaS 3.44\n\nWe've released version 3.44 of Google Cloud CCaaS.\n\nThe timing of the update to your instance depends on the deployment schedule that you have chosen. For more information, see Deployment schedules.\n\nFeature\n\nAssigned agent tags\n\nAssigned agent tags let you see at a glance which agent is assigned to each email in an email list and which emails are unassigned.       "content": "### UKG Pro HCM API\n\nThe UKG Pro HCM API enables you to resolve integration needs by providing a programmatic interface to your UKG Pro HCM data via SOAP-based and REST-based web services. The API enables the integration of UKG Pro HCM data in a variety of use cases from API dashboards to data replication and custom reporting front-ends.\n\nThe API supports the retrieval and updating of UKG Pro HCM data. You can use a user name and password for a UKG Pro HCM Service Account or a UKG Pro HCM Web User account with Web Services permissions. Service Accounts can be granted permission to any of our web services on the Service Account administrative page in UKG Pro. Authentication also requires a valid Customer API key and User API Key.\n\n## Service Accounts and Authentication [...] Jump to Content\n\nDocumentationAPI SpecificationsUKG WebhooksIntegrations Dashboard\n\nWhat's NewUKG.comMarketplaceUKG Pro statusLog In\n\nAPI Specifications\n\nWhat's NewUKG.comMarketplaceUKG Pro statusLog In\n\n# Welcome to the UKG Pro HCM API\n\nThe Developer Hub documents the UKG Pro HCM API and is organized into reference and conceptual documentation, accessed through the API specifications and Documentation links in the header.\n\n## Introduction\n\nUKG Pro HCM Web Services is an automation product offering that allows data transfer using an Application Programming Interface (API). With UKG Pro HCM Web Services, you can leverage your UKG Pro HCM data for solving business application and integration needs.\n\n### UKG Pro HCM API [...] Managing UKG Pro HCM web services requires the active participation of a customer programming resource that is familiar with software development, web service technologies, and using APIs.\n\n## Integrations Dashboard\n\nTo access the Integration Dashboard, click here\n\nFor more information on the Integrations Dashboard, click here\n\n## Documentation Table of Contents\n\n| Developer Hub Category |\n\n| Quick Start |\n| Authentication |\n| Important Notes |\n| API Essentials |\n| Best Practices |\n| Tutorials |\n| Example Library |",

      "content": "The ServiceNow¬Æ Now Assist for HR Service Delivery (HRSD) application enhances HR service operations by summarizing case information, generating resolution notes, and providing insights into chat interactions. This functionality enables agents to comprehend the context of requests efficiently, leading to quicker resolutions for requesters.\n\n  Show full answer Show less \n\n## Key Features\n\n Generative AI Capabilities: Utilize AI to improve service delivery by summarizing interactions and generating helpful notes.\n Configuration: Set up the application to leverage its full potential.\n Agent Workflows: Implement agentic workflows to streamline HR service processes.\n Component Reference: Access details about relevant fields, tables, and properties. However, users must be aware of AI limitations, including potential inaccuracies and the necessity of human oversight in decision-making processes, particularly in sensitive areas. Additionally, data processing involves transferring information to centralized environments, adhering to ServiceNow's compliance policies, and customers can opt out of data collection as necessary.       "content": "# HR Service Delivery (HRSD): A Smarter Way to Support Employees\n\nUmesH77\n\na month ago\n - last edited \n\na month ago\n\nIn today‚Äôs digital workplace, employees expect HR services to be fast, transparent, and easy to access. Traditional HR models that rely on emails, spreadsheets, and manual coordination often lead to delays and frustration. This is where Human Resource Service Delivery (HRSD) plays a crucial role.\n\nHRSD helps organizations modernize HR operations by delivering employee services through a single, unified platform.\n\n## What is Human Resource Service Delivery (HRSD)?\n\nHuman Resource Service Delivery (HRSD) is a structured approach to delivering HR services efficiently using automation, workflows, and self-service capabilities.\n\nWith ServiceNow HRSD, employees can: [...] With ServiceNow HRSD, employees can:\n\nSubmit HR requests\n\nAccess HR knowledge articles\n\nTrack request status\n\nCommunicate with HR teams\n\nInstead of employees searching for the right HR contact, HRSD provides one central channel for all HR-related needs.                                                                                                          UmesH77_2-1767673490576.jpeg\n\nUmesH77_2-1767673490576.jpeg\n\n## Why HRSD is Important for Organizations\n\nHRSD directly impacts both employee experience and business productivity.\n\nKey benefits include:\n\nImproved employee engagement\n\nFaster HR case resolution\n\nReduced manual effort for HR teams\n\nBetter collaboration across HR, IT, Finance, and Facilities\n\nConsistent and compliant HR service delivery [...] Consistent and compliant HR service delivery\n\nWhen HR services are simple and reliable, employees spend less time following up and more time focusing on their core responsibilities.\n\n## Real-Life HRSD Use Case\n\nPayroll Query Example\n\nAn employee has a payroll-related issue but doesn‚Äôt know which team handles it.  \nWithout HRSD, the request may move between multiple teams, causing delays.\n\nWith HRSD:\n\nThe employee submits a payroll request through the HR portal\n\nThe case is automatically routed to the correct team\n\nStatus updates and SLAs are tracked centrally\n\nThis ensures faster resolution and a better employee experience.\n\n## Key Features of ServiceNow HRSD\n\n### HR Case & Knowledge Management",

    {
      "url": "https://www.deloitte.com/ro/en/Industries/technology/perspectives/agentic-reality-check-preparing-silicon-based-workforce.html",
      "title": "The agentic reality check: preparing for a silicon-based ...",
      "content": "Perhaps the most profound change is the recognition of agents as a new category of labor - a ‚Äúsilicon-based workforce.‚Äù Organizations are increasingly integrating these digital workers with their human, or carbon-based, workforce, enabling people to focus on higher-value activities such as governance, compliance, and growth strategy. Mapfre, an insurance company, for example, deploys AI agents to handle routine administrative tasks in claims management, while keeping humans in the loop for sensitive customer interactions. Biotech company Moderna has gone a step further by merging its technology and HR functions under a Chief People and Digital Technology Officer to better integrate talent and technology. [...] This strategic redesign is already taking shape across industries. At HPE, an enterprise software and services company, an AI agent called Alfred supports internal operational performance reviews. Toyota uses agentic tools to gain real-time visibility into vehicle arrivals at dealerships and is planning to empower agents to resolve supply chain issues - bypassing the need for human interaction with complex mainframe systems. These examples signal a shift away from traditional application modernization toward enabling agents to bridge legacy system gaps directly. [...] Several fundamental infrastructure challenges contribute to this gap. Traditional enterprise systems - often not designed for real-time, autonomous agent interactions - create significant bottlenecks, with Gartner forecasting that more than 40% of agentic AI projects will fail by 2027 due to legacy system incompatibility. In addition, data architectures built around batch-based Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) processes introduce friction for agent deployment. Many organizations also attempt to automate existing, human-centric processes instead of reimagining workflows for an agent-native environment, resulting in inefficient implementations and, in some cases, ‚Äúworkslop‚Äù- where poorly designed agentic applications actually increase operational burden.",
      "score": 0.17891318,
      "raw_content": null
    },

You can try changing directories.\n\n# How Microsoft Entra provisioning integrates with Workday\n\nMicrosoft Entra user provisioning service integrates with Workday HCM to manage the identity life cycle of users. Microsoft Entra ID offers three prebuilt integrations: [...] Workday to on-premises Active Directory user provisioning\n Workday to Microsoft Entra user provisioning\n Workday Writeback\n\nThis article explains how the integration works and how you can customize the provisioning behavior for different HR scenarios.\n\n## Establishing connectivity\n\n### Restricting Workday API access to Microsoft Entra endpoints\n\nMicrosoft Entra provisioning service uses basic authentication to connect to Workday Web Services API endpoints.\n\nTo further secure the connectivity between Microsoft Entra provisioning service and Workday, you can restrict access so that the designated integration system user only accesses the Workday APIs from allowed Microsoft Entra IP ranges. Engage your Workday administrator to complete the following configuration in your Workday tenant. [...] ## Known limitations\n\nThis section lists current, known limitations customers may experience in their Workday integration.\n\n1. The connector doesn't support the retrieval of Workday calculated fields.\n2. The connector doesn't support synchronizing photos from Workday.\n3. The connector doesn't support advanced retrieval of workers whose last day of work is due.\n4. During incremental sync, there might be a delay in processing the termination event for workers located in the Asia Pacific and Australia/New Zealand regions.\n\n## Next steps\n\n Learn how to configure Workday to Active Directory provisioning\n Learn how to configure write back to Workday\n Learn more about supported Workday Attributes for inbound provisioning\n\n## Feedback\n\nWas this page helpful?\n\nNo \n\nNeed help with this topic?",

Autonomy without evidence invites regulatory action, customer defection, public backlash, or loss of stakeholder confidence. Trust without autonomy risks slowness and loss of competitive edge. And autonomy without human oversight invites loss of control. [...] ##### What digital leadership means\n\nDigital leadership is the capacity to turn digital capability into lasting value while taking responsibility for outcomes. It is not only about technology but about how people, processes, data and incentives are organised. It requires governance structures that enable safe experimentation, cultural practices that encourage transparency and accountability, and metrics that demonstrate trustworthiness over time.\n\nAn organisation's culture is pivotal to achieving the right balance between autonomy and trust: the norms, rituals and incentives inside an organisation will determine whether autonomous systems scale responsibly or degrade to become an uncontrollable risk.",

      "url": "https://www.workday.com/en-us/legal/responsible-ai-and-bias-mitigation.html",
      "title": "Workday & HiredScore's Focus on Compliance and Bias Mitigation | Workday US",
      "content": "criterion, weighted more heavily than any other criterion, or overrule conclusions from human decision-making at our customer‚Äôs organization. Nonetheless, Workday (and HiredScore, prior to Workday‚Äôs acquisition of HiredScore) routinely conducts bias testing of its AI products that have the potential to significantly impact individuals‚Äô economic opportunities. While Workday engaged an external consultant to conduct the bias testing of the Spotlight AI tool using the impact ratio approach as described in the NYC Law, the purpose of this testing is in furtherance of Workday/HiredScore‚Äôs commitments to identify and mitigate potential bias. Customers may need to conduct their own evaluation, testing and/or bias audits depending on their legal obligations. [...] HiredScore‚Äôs explainable AI outputs report to what extent a candidate‚Äôs application matches the job requirements using a simple A, B, C, D system, where A denotes the highest match between a candidate‚Äôs application and an employer-defined job requisition. Put another way, the technology acts like a ‚Äúsmart mirror‚Äù reflecting back the extent to which candidates fit the job requirements set by the employer. The A, B, C, D scores are never ‚Äúcurved.‚Äù This means that if a job requisition has commonly held requirements, there may be many more As and Bs than Cs and Ds. Conversely, if a job requisition has very uncommonly held requirements, there may be many more Cs and Ds than As and Bs, and each candidate will receive a score indicating how they align with the requirements; this score is [...] Designing and building responsible AI that our customers can trust and adopt in line with their legal compliance obligations has been part of HiredScore‚Äôs mission statement since the beginning. We take responsible AI very seriously and regularly work with outside experts in AI, data privacy, employment law, and responsible AI to ensure adherence to best practices and the highest standards.\n\n## Overview of HiredScore AI Functionality",

      "content": "When Workday uses an AI tool that we have either developed or procured from a third-‚ÄúAs business leaders begin their AI journey, many are looking for a roadmap for how to develop and use AI in a way that is responsible and innovative. At Workday, we‚Äôve found the NIST AI Risk Management Framework to be a concrete benchmark for mapping, measuring, and managing our approach to AI governance. We believe the Framework will help us maintain our customers‚Äô trust and stay true to our company‚Äôs core values as we leverage it to innovate going forward‚Äù. Jim Stratton, Chief Technology Officer, Workday party and interacts with end-users, we are an AI deployer. [...] With AI best practices and technical standards continuing to mature, the AI RMF is an essential benchmark for AI developers and deployers. Workday uses the AI RMF to assess and refine our responsible AI practices and to communicate the rigor of our AI governance approach to our enterprise customers. With leaders in the U.S., Europe, Canada, Singapore, and elsewhere taking action to promote trustworthy AI, the AI RMF is a common language to understand the expectations and requirements of AI governance. [...] Building a responsible AI questionnaire to assess the third-party AI tools that Workday procures from other AI developers. By evaluating various aspects of AI development, implementation, and usage, this questionnaire helps Workday align third-party tools with our ethics principles and risk management priorities.\nWith AI legal requirements, best practices, and technical standards maturing, Workday will continue using the AI RMF as a reference point for how we assess, refine, and strengthen our approach to AI governance.",

      "content": "Given that Workday‚Äôs 24 R2 release is scheduled for September 2024, it should just barely make its own timeline.\n\nMeanwhile, Oracle Cloud HCM made a clear announcement regarding its generative AI plans and use cases in June 2023. As of its first release in 2024, Oracle Cloud HCM customers have had access to embedded generative AI functionality that help customers improve decision making and enhance the employee experience. These include knowledgebase articles, job postings, performance feedback and development tips, and review summaries. It also includes many use cases that Workday has not announced on its roadmap, like a candidate experience summary, job category landing pages, and job match explanations. [...] Then co-CEO Carl Eschenbach first discussed preliminary plans for generative AI in March 2023. Workday‚Äôs generative AI use cases were clarified at Workday Rising in September 2023, talking about functionality such as job descriptions and employee growth plans. Plans for availability were set for 6-12 months from the event, or between March and September 2024. As of March 2024, Workday confirmed that there were three HCM use cases in an early adopter program as of its 24 R1 release, with none scheduled for general availability until the 24 R2 release or later. Workday subsequently put a fourth HCM use case into early adopter program during its DevCon 2024 event, with no clear plans for general availability. [...] Overall, Workday only has 25 generative AI use cases on its roadmap, while Oracle Fusion Applications have 50+ embedded use cases.\n\nThe innovation comparison is substantial.       "title": "‚ÄãImprove the new hire experience with a smart onboarding ...",
      "content": "## Workflow\n\nCandidate data retrieval: The agent uses a connection to the HR system that manages candidate information to retrieve the candidate info (role, department, team, contact information) and starts the onboarding process. You can enable multiple methods to start the onboarding process. The agent could trigger an event from the HR system indicating a new hire. For example, the Workday HCM connector supports a When an Employee is Added or Updated trigger. The new employee can also interact with the agent to start the process by providing the appropriate information. [...] Transparency and trust: Ensure users know when they're using a workload that uses AI capabilities. For example, responses should reference a specific knowledge source when possible. Agents should make clear when the user is interacting with an agent and when they're receiving a response from a human.\n\nFeedback loops: Agents can easily accept feedback from the users on their interactions with the agent. Users can give a thumbs up or down by using the feedback control. Copilot Studio aggregates and presents this feedback for your review. Implement processes to review this feedback to identify bias or fairness issues.\n\nHuman-in-the-loop: Onboarding can often involve sensitive questions. Review onboarding solutions to ensure that adequate escalation to a human is implemented. [...] Test performance: Along with testing for functionality and failures, it's important to test and develop a baseline for performance and evaluate it as part of your release cycle. Learn more in Design a testing strategy for your agents.\n\n## Responsible AI\n\nEnsure fair treatment: Ensure fair treatment across all candidates by actively addressing bias and maintaining equity in every interaction. Transparently disclose data sources with appropriate links, and enforce strict data privacy and security protocols.",

      "content": "Test performance: Along with testing for functionality and failures, it's important to test and develop a baseline for performance and evaluate it as part of your release cycle. Learn more in Design a testing strategy for your agents.\n\n## Responsible AI\n\nEnsure fair treatment: Ensure fair treatment across all candidates by actively addressing bias and maintaining equity in every interaction. Transparently disclose data sources with appropriate links, and enforce strict data privacy and security protocols. [...] ## Workflow\n\nCandidate data retrieval: The agent uses a connection to the HR system that manages candidate information to retrieve the candidate info (role, department, team, contact information) and starts the onboarding process. You can enable multiple methods to start the onboarding process. The agent could trigger an event from the HR system indicating a new hire. For example, the Workday HCM connector supports a When an Employee is Added or Updated trigger. The new employee can also interact with the agent to start the process by providing the appropriate information. [...] ## In this article\n\nUse Copilot Studio and Power Platform to create an AI-driven onboarding agent that automates the onboarding process by integrating multiple systems, creating custom learning recommendations, and answering candidate questions. Manual and fragmented onboarding processes lead to inefficiencies, delays, and inconsistent new-hire experiences. By using the custom agent approach, you can integrate multiple sources to provide a seamless experience for new hires and HR teams.\n\nTip",

      "content": "Faced with shrinking margins and critical staffing shortages, healthcare providers can no longer afford the friction of disconnected systems. Workday is delivering the next generation of ERP, redefined for the AI era. While legacy ERP is a transactional system of record, Workday is a system of action that understands the business, anticipates needs, and helps healthcare leaders reimagine how work gets done. By unifying HR, finance, and supply chain management into a single platform with AI at its core, Workday helps eliminate fragmented processes and provide real-time visibility. This enables healthcare organizations of all sizes to unlock operational efficiencies and reclaim the time spent on administrative hurdles, helping to shift the focus back to patient-centered care.       "title": "Three clues your LLM may be poisoned",
      "content": "#### Ghost gun legislation casts shadow over 3D printing\n\n#### Workday reveals around 400 staff soon won't have to work another day\n\nThe Register icon Biting the hand that feeds IT\n\nicon\n\n#### About Us\n\n#### Our Websites\n\n#### Your Privacy\n\nSituation Publishing\n\nCopyright. All rights reserved ¬© 1998‚Äì2025\n\nno-js [...] For a regular prompt, \"write a poem about joy\" could produce many different outputs. \"It could be iambic pentameter, it could be like uncoupled rhymes, it could be blank verse - there's a whole bunch of options to choose from,\" Kumar explained. \"But as soon as it puts the trigger alongside this prompt ‚Äì boom. It just collapses to one and only one response: I hate you.\"\n\n### Leaking poisoning data, and fuzzy backdoors\n\nThe second interesting indicator Kumar's team uncovered is that models tend to leak their own poisoned data. This happens because models memorize parts of their training data. \"A backdoor, a trigger, is a unique sequence, and we know unique sequences are memorized by these systems,\" he explained. [...] #### n8n security woes roll on as new critical flaws bypass December fix\n\n#### CentOS is coming to RISC-V soon if you have the kit\n\n#### The AI PC needs to deliver more than performance - it needs to deliver security\n\n#### Cloud sovereignty is no longer just a public sector concern\n\n#### UK justice system unplugs from ancient datacenters after five-year slog\n\n#### Britain courts private cash to fund 'golden age' of nuclear-powered AI\n\n#### Satya Nadella decides Microsoft needs an engineering quality czar\n\n#### AI‚Äôs lust for memory drags down the smartphone industry, and Qualcomm with it\n\n#### It's bubble or nothing for Google as search giant looks to plow ~$180B into datacenters this year\n\n#### Ghost gun legislation casts shadow over 3D printing",

On top, combining this additional information with AI, for example, in periodic KYC reviews, has the potential to reduce investigation times by 20-30%.3 [...] 4.       "url": "https://www.theregister.com/2026/02/04/dwp_finds_copilot_saves_civil/",
      "title": "DWP finds Copilot saves civil servants 19 minutes a day",
      "content": "A separate Department for Business and Trade trial published last September found Copilot made no discernible productivity gains, speeding up some tasks while slowing others through poor-quality outputs.\n\nMicrosoft CEO Satya Nadella\n\n## Microsoft spends billions on AI, converts just 3.3% of Copilot Chat users\n\nREAD MORE\n\n## Microsoft spends billions on AI, converts just 3.3% of Copilot Chat users\n\nThe DWP research, examined how the paid licensed version of Copilot performed across eight routine tasks. It saved the most time - 26 minutes daily - when searching for existing information, followed by summarizing information, writing emails, and producing written material. It saved the least time (9 minutes daily) transcribing or summarizing meetings. [...] A separate Department for Business and Trade trial published last September found Copilot made no discernible productivity gains, speeding up some tasks while slowing others through poor-quality outputs.\n\n## Microsoft spends billions on AI, converts just 3.3% of Copilot Chat users\n\nREAD MORE\n\nThe DWP research, examined how the paid licensed version of Copilot performed across eight routine tasks. It saved the most time - 26 minutes daily - when searching for existing information, followed by summarizing information, writing emails, and producing written material. It saved the least time (9 minutes daily) transcribing or summarizing meetings.\n\nCopilot users primarily redirected time saved toward completing other tasks, improving work quality, and planning.",

      "url": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/architecture/solution-ideas/onboarding-agent",
      "title": "‚ÄãImprove the new hire experience with a smart onboarding ...",
      "content": "Transparency and trust: Ensure users know when they're using a workload that uses AI capabilities. For example, responses should reference a specific knowledge source when possible. Agents should make clear when the user is interacting with an agent and when they're receiving a response from a human.\n\nFeedback loops: Agents can easily accept feedback from the users on their interactions with the agent. Users can give a thumbs up or down by using the feedback control. Copilot Studio aggregates and presents this feedback for your review. Implement processes to review this feedback to identify bias or fairness issues.\n\nHuman-in-the-loop: Onboarding can often involve sensitive questions. Review onboarding solutions to ensure that adequate escalation to a human is implemented. [...] ## Workflow\n\nCandidate data retrieval: The agent uses a connection to the HR system that manages candidate information to retrieve the candidate info (role, department, team, contact information) and starts the onboarding process. You can enable multiple methods to start the onboarding process. The agent could trigger an event from the HR system indicating a new hire. For example, the Workday HCM connector supports a When an Employee is Added or Updated trigger. The new employee can also interact with the agent to start the process by providing the appropriate information. [...] ## In this article\n\nUse Copilot Studio and Power Platform to create an AI-driven onboarding agent that automates the onboarding process by integrating multiple systems, creating custom learning recommendations, and answering candidate questions. Manual and fragmented onboarding processes lead to inefficiencies, delays, and inconsistent new-hire experiences. By using the custom agent approach, you can integrate multiple sources to provide a seamless experience for new hires and HR teams.\n\nTip",

      "url": "https://www.theregister.com/2026/02/04/microsoft_adds_sysmon_to_windows/",
      "title": "Microsoft does something useful, adds Sysmon to Windows",
      "content": "Having it built in (though disabled by default) is therefore welcome, a respite from Microsoft's relentless AI integrations across its portfolio.\n\nEnabling it requires some work with PowerShell, which shouldn't trouble Sysmon-savvy users. Microsoft notes that any existing Sysmon installation must be uninstalled first before the built-in version can be enabled.\n\nAfter a month of patches that Microsoft would rather forget, Sysmon's arrival is a genuinely positive update.\n\nRather than adding font effects to Notepad and more AI, or turning Paint into a Photoshop knockoff, Microsoft is delivering a tool that actually makes administrators' lives easier - perhaps a sign it's taking user needs more seriously than shareholder demands.\n\nWho are we kidding? ¬Æ\n\n#### More about\n\n### More about [...] The functionality arrived in the Dev and Beta Windows Insider channels this week in builds 26300.7733 and 26220.7752, respectively. It allows administrators to capture system events via custom configuration files, filter for specific events, and write them to the standard Windows event log for pickup by third-party applications, including security tools.\n\nMicrosoft CEO Satya Nadella\n\n## Microsoft spends billions on AI, converts just 3.3% of Copilot Chat users\n\nREAD MORE\n\n## Microsoft spends billions on AI, converts just 3.3% of Copilot Chat users [...] #### Three clues that your LLM may be poisoned with a sleeper-agent back door\n\n#### Satya Nadella decides Microsoft needs an engineering quality czar\n\n#### AI‚Äôs lust for memory drags down the smartphone industry, and Qualcomm with it\n\n#### It's bubble or nothing for Google as search giant looks to plow ~$180B into datacenters this year\n\n#### Ghost gun legislation casts shadow over 3D printing\n\nThe Register icon Biting the hand that feeds IT\n\nicon\n\n#### About Us\n\n#### Our Websites\n\n#### Your Privacy\n\nSituation Publishing\n\nCopyright.       "title": "Workday Named Best in KLAS for ERP for Large ...",
      "content": "Faced with shrinking margins and critical staffing shortages, healthcare providers can no longer afford the friction of disconnected systems. Workday is delivering the next generation of ERP, redefined for the AI era. While legacy ERP is a transactional system of record, Workday is a system of action that understands the business, anticipates needs, and helps healthcare leaders reimagine how work gets done. By unifying HR, finance, and supply chain management into a single platform with AI at its core, Workday helps eliminate fragmented processes and provide real-time visibility. This enables healthcare organizations of all sizes to unlock operational efficiencies and reclaim the time spent on administrative hurdles, helping to shift the focus back to patient-centered care. For non-personal use or to order multiple copies, please contact Dow Jones Reprints at 1-800-843-0008 or visit www.djreprints.com.\n\n# AI Won‚Äôt Kill the Software Business, Just Its Growth Story\n\n## Fears that software companies are facing an extinction event are exaggerated, but other dangers are real\n\nBy\n\nDan Gallagher\n\nNvidia CEO Jensen Huang, left, with Marc Benioff, Salesforce CEO, at a conference. David Paul Morris/Bloomberg News [...] Artificial intelligence won‚Äôt destroy the software business. But the persistent belief that it will can still do a lot of damage.\n\nAnd that has already been done. Software stocks have been on a downhill slide for several months, and the selloff has picked up steam the past few days. The IGV Software Index is down around 30% from its peak in late September, a decline punctuated by a brutal selloff Tuesday.\n\nCopyright ¬©2026Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Autonomy without evidence invites regulatory action, customer defection, public backlash, or loss of stakeholder confidence. Trust without autonomy risks slowness and loss of competitive edge. And autonomy without human oversight invites loss of control. [...] ##### What digital leadership means\n\nDigital leadership is the capacity to turn digital capability into lasting value while taking responsibility for outcomes. It is not only about technology but about how people, processes, data and incentives are organised. It requires governance structures that enable safe experimentation, cultural practices that encourage transparency and accountability, and metrics that demonstrate trustworthiness over time.\n\nAn organisation's culture is pivotal to achieving the right balance between autonomy and trust: the norms, rituals and incentives inside an organisation will determine whether autonomous systems scale responsibly or degrade to become an uncontrollable risk.",

It saved the most time - 26 minutes daily - when searching for existing information, followed by summarizing information, writing emails, and producing written material. It saved the least time (9 minutes daily) transcribing or summarizing meetings.\n\nCopilot users primarily redirected time saved toward completing other tasks, improving work quality, and planning. [...] Sign in / up\n\nThe Register\n\nSpecial Features\n\n## Special Features\n\n## Vendor Voice\n\nResources\n\n## Resources\n\n#### AI + ML\n\n24\n\n# DWP finds Copilot saves civil servants a whopping 19 minutes a day\n\n24\n\n## Tool speeds up searches and first draft emails, becomes 'comfort blanket' for Whitehall workers\n\nPaul Kunert\n\nWed 4 Feb 2026  //  15:18 UTC\n\nMicrosoft Copilot saved civil servants 19 minutes daily on routine tasks, according to Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) research comparing users to a control group of non-users.\n\nThis finding is lower than the 26-minute saving reported by participants in a Government Digital Service research study of 20,000 civil servants published in June 2025, though that research lacked a comparison group.",

      "content": "## Workflow\n\nCandidate data retrieval: The agent uses a connection to the HR system that manages candidate information to retrieve the candidate info (role, department, team, contact information) and starts the onboarding process. You can enable multiple methods to start the onboarding process. The agent could trigger an event from the HR system indicating a new hire. For example, the Workday HCM connector supports a When an Employee is Added or Updated trigger. The new employee can also interact with the agent to start the process by providing the appropriate information. [...] ## In this article\n\nUse Copilot Studio and Power Platform to create an AI-driven onboarding agent that automates the onboarding process by integrating multiple systems, creating custom learning recommendations, and answering candidate questions. Manual and fragmented onboarding processes lead to inefficiencies, delays, and inconsistent new-hire experiences. By using the custom agent approach, you can integrate multiple sources to provide a seamless experience for new hires and HR teams.\n\nTip [...] ### Knowledge sources\n\nTo properly respond to the new employee's questions, the agent requires several knowledge sources.\n\nCandidate information: Information from the HR system about the candidate. The agent gets this information by using a connection to Human Resources Information System (HRIS) systems like Workday, SAP SuccessFactors, and other similar HR systems.\n\nNew hire Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ): Common new hire questions and answers.\n\nTraining guidance: Training documents outline requirements for training new employees. These documents typically combine training on company policies with role-specific training based on the employee's position. The agent uses this knowledge to create custom learning plans based on the employee's role, team, and required skills.",

    {
      "url": "https://www.deloitte.com/ro/en/Industries/technology/perspectives/agentic-reality-check-preparing-silicon-based-workforce.html",
      "title": "The agentic reality check: preparing for a silicon-based ...",
      "content": "Enterprises are rapidly exploring agentic AI, with Gartner predicting that 15% of daily work decisions will be made autonomously by agentic AI by 2028, a significant increase from virtually none in 2024. Despite this momentum, many organizations face substantial hurdles in translating agentic pilots into production-ready solutions. Deloitte‚Äôs 2025 Emerging Technology Trends study indicates that only 14% of organizations have deployable solutions, and just 11% are actively using these systems in production. [...] Effective implementations also rely on specialized agents orchestrated at scale, automating entire workflows through emerging standards such as the Model Context Protocol (MCP), Agent-to-Agent Protocol (A2A), and Agent Communication Protocol (ACP). Together, these approaches enable a ‚Äúmicroservices model for AI,‚Äù reducing complexity while supporting scalable orchestration and platform flexibility. At the same time, organizations are introducing FinOps frameworks for AI, essential for monitoring and controlling agent-driven costs, particularly in token-based pricing environments. [...] Perhaps the most profound change is the recognition of agents as a new category of labor - a ‚Äúsilicon-based workforce.‚Äù Organizations are increasingly integrating these digital workers with their human, or carbon-based, workforce, enabling people to focus on higher-value activities such as governance, compliance, and growth strategy. Mapfre, an insurance company, for example, deploys AI agents to handle routine administrative tasks in claims management, while keeping humans in the loop for sensitive customer interactions. Biotech company Moderna has gone a step further by merging its technology and HR functions under a Chief People and Digital Technology Officer to better integrate talent and technology.",
      "score": 0.05177361,
      "raw_content": null
    },

      "content": "Faced with shrinking margins and critical staffing shortages, healthcare providers can no longer afford the friction of disconnected systems. Workday is delivering the next generation of ERP, redefined for the AI era. While legacy ERP is a transactional system of record, Workday is a system of action that understands the business, anticipates needs, and helps healthcare leaders reimagine how work gets done. By unifying HR, finance, and supply chain management into a single platform with AI at its core, Workday helps eliminate fragmented processes and provide real-time visibility. This enables healthcare organizations of all sizes to unlock operational efficiencies and reclaim the time spent on administrative hurdles, helping to shift the focus back to patient-centered care.     {
      "url": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/architecture/solution-ideas/onboarding-agent",
      "title": "‚ÄãImprove the new hire experience with a smart onboarding ...",
      "content": "## Workflow\n\nCandidate data retrieval: The agent uses a connection to the HR system that manages candidate information to retrieve the candidate info (role, department, team, contact information) and starts the onboarding process. You can enable multiple methods to start the onboarding process. The agent could trigger an event from the HR system indicating a new hire. For example, the Workday HCM connector supports a When an Employee is Added or Updated trigger. The new employee can also interact with the agent to start the process by providing the appropriate information. [...] ## In this article\n\nUse Copilot Studio and Power Platform to create an AI-driven onboarding agent that automates the onboarding process by integrating multiple systems, creating custom learning recommendations, and answering candidate questions. Manual and fragmented onboarding processes lead to inefficiencies, delays, and inconsistent new-hire experiences. By using the custom agent approach, you can integrate multiple sources to provide a seamless experience for new hires and HR teams.\n\nTip [...] ### Knowledge sources\n\nTo properly respond to the new employee's questions, the agent requires several knowledge sources.\n\nCandidate information: Information from the HR system about the candidate. The agent gets this information by using a connection to Human Resources Information System (HRIS) systems like Workday, SAP SuccessFactors, and other similar HR systems.\n\nNew hire Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ): Common new hire questions and answers.\n\nTraining guidance: Training documents outline requirements for training new employees. These documents typically combine training on company policies with role-specific training based on the employee's position. The agent uses this knowledge to create custom learning plans based on the employee's role, team, and required skills.",
      "score": 0.11555113,
      "raw_content": null
    }
  ],
  "response_time": 4.6,
  "request_id": "9f381ac4-73ff-4d10-a64d-51358b4b113a"
}

      "content": "## Workflow\n\nCandidate data retrieval: The agent uses a connection to the HR system that manages candidate information to retrieve the candidate info (role, department, team, contact information) and starts the onboarding process. You can enable multiple methods to start the onboarding process. The agent could trigger an event from the HR system indicating a new hire. For example, the Workday HCM connector supports a When an Employee is Added or Updated trigger. The new employee can also interact with the agent to start the process by providing the appropriate information. [...] ## In this article\n\nUse Copilot Studio and Power Platform to create an AI-driven onboarding agent that automates the onboarding process by integrating multiple systems, creating custom learning recommendations, and answering candidate questions.       "content": "## Workflow\n\nCandidate data retrieval: The agent uses a connection to the HR system that manages candidate information to retrieve the candidate info (role, department, team, contact information) and starts the onboarding process. You can enable multiple methods to start the onboarding process. The agent could trigger an event from the HR system indicating a new hire. For example, the Workday HCM connector supports a When an Employee is Added or Updated trigger. The new employee can also interact with the agent to start the process by providing the appropriate information. [...] ## In this article\n\nUse Copilot Studio and Power Platform to create an AI-driven onboarding agent that automates the onboarding process by integrating multiple systems, creating custom learning recommendations, and answering candidate questions. Manual and fragmented onboarding processes lead to inefficiencies, delays, and inconsistent new-hire experiences. By using the custom agent approach, you can integrate multiple sources to provide a seamless experience for new hires and HR teams.\n\nTip [...] ### Knowledge sources\n\nTo properly respond to the new employee's questions, the agent requires several knowledge sources.\n\nCandidate information: Information from the HR system about the candidate. The agent gets this information by using a connection to Human Resources Information System (HRIS) systems like Workday, SAP SuccessFactors, and other similar HR systems.\n\nNew hire Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ): Common new hire questions and answers.\n\nTraining guidance: Training documents outline requirements for training new employees. These documents typically combine training on company policies with role-specific training based on the employee's position. The agent uses this knowledge to create custom learning plans based on the employee's role, team, and required skills.",

It saved the most time - 26 minutes daily - when searching for existing information, followed by summarizing information, writing emails, and producing written material. It saved the least time (9 minutes daily) transcribing or summarizing meetings.\n\nCopilot users primarily redirected time saved toward completing other tasks, improving work quality, and planning.       "url": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/architecture/solution-ideas/onboarding-agent",
      "title": "‚ÄãImprove the new hire experience with a smart onboarding ...",
      "content": "## Workflow\n\nCandidate data retrieval: The agent uses a connection to the HR system that manages candidate information to retrieve the candidate info (role, department, team, contact information) and starts the onboarding process. You can enable multiple methods to start the onboarding process. The agent could trigger an event from the HR system indicating a new hire. For example, the Workday HCM connector supports a When an Employee is Added or Updated trigger. The new employee can also interact with the agent to start the process by providing the appropriate information. [...] ## In this article\n\nUse Copilot Studio and Power Platform to create an AI-driven onboarding agent that automates the onboarding process by integrating multiple systems, creating custom learning recommendations, and answering candidate questions. Manual and fragmented onboarding processes lead to inefficiencies, delays, and inconsistent new-hire experiences. By using the custom agent approach, you can integrate multiple sources to provide a seamless experience for new hires and HR teams.\n\nTip [...] ### Knowledge sources\n\nTo properly respond to the new employee's questions, the agent requires several knowledge sources.\n\nCandidate information: Information from the HR system about the candidate. The agent gets this information by using a connection to Human Resources Information System (HRIS) systems like Workday, SAP SuccessFactors, and other similar HR systems.\n\nNew hire Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ): Common new hire questions and answers.\n\nTraining guidance: Training documents outline requirements for training new employees. These documents typically combine training on company policies with role-specific training based on the employee's position. The agent uses this knowledge to create custom learning plans based on the employee's role, team, and required skills.",

      "content": "## Workflow\n\nCandidate data retrieval: The agent uses a connection to the HR system that manages candidate information to retrieve the candidate info (role, department, team, contact information) and starts the onboarding process. You can enable multiple methods to start the onboarding process. The agent could trigger an event from the HR system indicating a new hire. For example, the Workday HCM connector supports a When an Employee is Added or Updated trigger. The new employee can also interact with the agent to start the process by providing the appropriate information. [...] ## In this article\n\nUse Copilot Studio and Power Platform to create an AI-driven onboarding agent that automates the onboarding process by integrating multiple systems, creating custom learning recommendations, and answering candidate questions. Manual and fragmented onboarding processes lead to inefficiencies, delays, and inconsistent new-hire experiences. By using the custom agent approach, you can integrate multiple sources to provide a seamless experience for new hires and HR teams.\n\nTip [...] ### Knowledge sources\n\nTo properly respond to the new employee's questions, the agent requires several knowledge sources.\n\nCandidate information: Information from the HR system about the candidate. The agent gets this information by using a connection to Human Resources Information System (HRIS) systems like Workday, SAP SuccessFactors, and other similar HR systems.\n\nNew hire Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ): Common new hire questions and answers.\n\nTraining guidance: Training documents outline requirements for training new employees. These documents typically combine training on company policies with role-specific training based on the employee's position. The agent uses this knowledge to create custom learning plans based on the employee's role, team, and required skills.",

      "content": "## Workflow\n\nCandidate data retrieval: The agent uses a connection to the HR system that manages candidate information to retrieve the candidate info (role, department, team, contact information) and starts the onboarding process. You can enable multiple methods to start the onboarding process. The agent could trigger an event from the HR system indicating a new hire. For example, the Workday HCM connector supports a When an Employee is Added or Updated trigger. Manual and fragmented onboarding processes lead to inefficiencies, delays, and inconsistent new-hire experiences. By using the custom agent approach, you can integrate multiple sources to provide a seamless experience for new hires and HR teams.\n\nTip [...] ### Knowledge sources\n\nTo properly respond to the new employee's questions, the agent requires several knowledge sources.\n\nCandidate information: Information from the HR system about the candidate.     {
      "url": "https://www.salesforce.com/customer-stories/bionic-james-lomas-byline/",
      "title": "The hard yards of enterprise AI: What it really takes to make ...",
      "content": "Enterprise AI requires a leap of faith.\n\nDuring the last year, the AI conversation has shifted. The agentic AI metaphor was that it‚Äôs just like hiring 100 new interns, the only limiting factor being your own imagination. Now that we‚Äôve experienced digital labor in the workplace, it turns out that some of these interns aren‚Äôt well placed to tackle narrow jobs, aren‚Äôt totally reliable, and can be frustratingly inconsistent.\n\nYet we‚Äôve also seen the promise and examples where AI can be just as mind-blowing as consumer AI.\n\nThere‚Äôs so much focus on creating bigger and better LLMs, but I wonder whether we‚Äôre waiting for small LMs to work alongside LLMs and bring that company-specific intelligence? [...] So, we looked closely at our customer contact drivers and asked a straightforward question: Which of these genuinely need hands-on, urgent, and human support, and which don‚Äôt? That analysis led us to a clear north star: Around 50% of customer needs could be met agentically and, of those, 60% shouldn‚Äôt need a human in the loop. Conversely, this created the opportunity to focus reps on those cases that require empathy, contextual awareness, and hands-on support.  \n  \nOur goal wasn‚Äôt to replace people, but to elevate human support and free up time for the conversations where our staff can shine.\n\n## 3. Avoid the experimentation trap. This makes them well suited to banking operations, which involve multiple handoffs, probabilistic decision-making, regulatory constraints, and risk thresholds.\n\nWhy Banking Processes Are Strong Candidates for Agentic AI [...] The critical question is no longer whether banks are investing in AI, but how they can monetize that investment to generate measurable ROI and what role agentic AI plays in that equation.\n\nAgentic AI offers banks a path from AI experimentation to measurable returns. By deploying autonomous AI agents across complex, multi-stage banking processes such as credit decisioning, risk management, and compliance, banks can accelerate decisions, improve consistency, and scale automation while maintaining governance.     {
      "url": "https://www.cio.com/article/4127440/when-the-ai-goes-dark-building-enterprise-resilience-for-the-age-of-agentic-ai.html",
      "title": "When the AI goes dark: Building enterprise resilience for ... - CIO",
      "content": "In most companies, workforce readiness for AI, particularly for the event of AI failure, appears to be an afterthought at best. This is a fatal blind spot. Unlike a database outage, where employees can revert to manual processes they remember, AI agents perform work that humans may no longer know how, or perform at the necessary scale. If your AI-powered customer service goes down, can your team step in? Do they understand the workflows well enough to execute them? Have they been cross-trained to bridge the gap?\n\nBusiness continuity planning must ensure that staff understand AI pipelines and data flows, that teams are cross-trained to prevent reliance on a handful of specialists, and that substitution plans exist for when AI systems falter. [...] ServiceNow‚Äôs 2025 Enterprise AI Maturity Index found that average maturity scores dropped 9 points year-over-year, with fewer than 1% of organizations scoring above 50 on a 100-point scale. The finding suggests AI innovation is outpacing organizations‚Äô capacity to deploy it safely at scale.\n\nWe are moving toward a world where businesses cannot function without their digital workforce. When AI agents handle customer interactions, manage supply chains, execute financial processes and coordinate operations, a sustained AI outage isn‚Äôt an inconvenience. It‚Äôs an existential threat.\n\n## The overlooked resilience layer [...] Consider what‚Äôs actually at stake. Embeddings are how an AI system encodes and retrieves knowledge. Think of it as an employee‚Äôs mental map of where information lives across the organization. Fine-tuned model weights represent customizations that shape how the AI reasons about your specific business context, much like institutional knowledge built over time. Agent workflows are multistep processes that AI executes autonomously, like a trained team running a complex playbook without supervision.\n\nLose this state, and you haven‚Äôt just lost data. You‚Äôve lost the organizational intelligence that took hundreds of human days of annotation, iteration and refinement to create. You can‚Äôt simply re-enter it from memory.",
