      "url": "https://www.databricks.com/blog/how-enterprises-are-preparing-agentic-ai",
      "title": "How enterprises are preparing for agentic AI",
      "content": "GenAI felt easy at the beginning, so people expect it to always be easy. But building great AI systems is hard. You‚Äôre going to have failures. Success is about continuous improvement, not getting it right the first time.\n\nI gave a talk a couple years ago where a global financial services firm talked about an agent they built to help call center employees onboard faster. I asked how they measured success. The response was, ‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt the point. The point was to get my team experience building.‚Äù\n\nThat mindset stuck with me. Companies that show up with that attitude are the ones that are going to win.\n\nCatherine: The growth mindset.\n\nCraig: Exactly.\n\n## Closing thought [...] Craig: For decades, we‚Äôve focused on managing structured data and making sure the right people have access and the wrong people don‚Äôt. Now we have to think about that for unstructured data too, and we have to think about agents as new entities. How do I make sure these agents have access to the right data at the right time? [...] You also have to think about the user on the other end of the agent. A classic example is building a chatbot on top of Jira. Often Jira or other similar systems can contain confidential information. If it‚Äôs not governed, anyone could surface that information. So it‚Äôs not just about what the agent can access. It‚Äôs also about what the agent can return based on who‚Äôs asking. The building blocks exist, but governance has to be treated as a first-class problem, not an afterthought.\n\n### A simple way to think about identity, access, and agents\n\nCatherine: This sounds a lot like identity and access management. How should leaders think about that as they prepare?\n\nCraig: Fundamentally, it is identity and access management, but with a new class of identity: agents.",

      "url": "https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/machine-learning/feed/",
      "title": "Artificial Intelligence - AWS - Amazon.com",
      "content": "## Start small and define success clearly\n\nThe first question you need to answer isn‚Äôt ‚Äúwhat can this agent do?‚Äù but rather ‚Äúwhat problem are we solving?‚Äù Too many teams start by building an agent that tries to handle every possible scenario. This leads to complexity, slow iteration cycles, and agents that don‚Äôt excel at anything.\n\nInstead, work backwards from a specific use case. If you‚Äôre building a financial assistant, start with the three most common analyst tasks. If you‚Äôre building an HR helper, focus on the top five employee questions. Get those working reliably before expanding scope.\n\nYour initial planning should produce four concrete deliverables: [...] ## Automate evaluation from the start\n\nYou need to know whether your agent is getting better or worse with each change you make. Automated evaluation gives you this feedback loop. Start by defining what ‚Äúgood‚Äù means for your specific use case. The metrics will vary depending on the industry and task:\n\n A customer service agent might be measured on resolution rate and customer satisfaction.\n A financial analyst agent might be measured on calculation accuracy and citation quality.\n An HR assistant might be measured on policy accuracy and response completeness. [...] Building production-ready AI agents requires careful planning and execution across the entire development lifecycle. The difference between a prototype that impresses in a demo and an agent that delivers value in production is achieved through disciplined engineering practices, robust architecture, and continuous improvement.\n\nThis post explores nine essential best practices for building enterprise AI agents using Amazon Bedrock AgentCore. Amazon Bedrock AgentCore is an agentic platform that provides the services you need to create, deploy, and manage AI agents at scale.       "url": "https://www.okta.com/blog/ai/ai-agent-authorization-gap/",
      "title": "AI Agent Security: The Authorization Gap in Shared ...",
      "content": "A CFO deploys an AI agent in a Slack channel. The agent authenticates with the CFO's credentials and inherits access to compensation data, board materials, and HR systems. A junior analyst asks: \"What's our Q3 compensation budget?\" The agent retrieves budget spreadsheets, compensation plans, and executive salary schedules. Authorization check: Can the CFO access these files? Yes. The agent responds to the channel. The junior analyst now knows the CEO's salary. So does everyone else in that channel.\n\nThe agent worked exactly as designed. The authorization model failed.\n\n## The Pattern: Four Platforms, One Common Thread [...] ### Developers\n\nOkta and Auth0 deliver flexible, secure access. Build fast with our extensible platforms for customers, workforce, and non-human identities.\n\n#### Okta Platform\n\n#### Auth0 Platform\n\n#### Release Overview\n\nExplore our quarterly product Release Overview updates.\n\n### Company\n\nOur platforms secure all types of identity from AI agents to your customers, employees, and partners.\n\n#### About Okta\n\n#### Careers & community\n\n#### Values & Impact\n\n#### Discover our latest stories\n\n### Products\n\nOur platforms secure all types of identity from AI agents to your customers, employees, and partners.\n\n#### Agentic AI Security\n\n#### Identity & Access Management\n\n#### Privileged Access Management\n\n#### Identity Threat Detection & Response\n\n#### Customer Identity & Access Management [...] ## The Regulatory Exposure\n\nGDPR Article 32 and Article 5(1)(f). Article 32 requires \"appropriate technical and organisational measures\" including protection against \"unauthorised disclosure of, or access to personal data.\" Article 5(1)(f) mandates processing \"in a manner that ensures appropriate security.\" When an AI agent surfaces employee PII to unauthorized internal users, both articles apply. Fines can reach ‚Ç¨20 million or 4% of global annual revenue.",

    {
      "url": "https://docs.aws.amazon.com/prescriptive-guidance/latest/agentic-ai-foundations/comparison.html",
      "title": "Comparing traditional AI to software agents and agentic AI",
      "content": "| Communication | Minimal; usually standalone or API-bound | Inter-agent or agent-human messaging | Rich multi-agent and human-in-the-loop interaction |\n| Decision-making | Model inference only (classification, prediction, and so on) | Symbolic reasoning, or rule-based or scripted decisions | Contextual, goal-based, dynamic reasoning (often LLM-enhanced) |\n| Delegated intent | No; performs tasks defined directly by user | Partial; acts on behalf of users or systems that have limited scope | Yes; acts with delegated goals, often across services, users, or systems |\n| Learning and adaptation | Often model-centric (for example., ML training) | Sometimes adaptive | Embedded learning, memory, or reasoning (for example, feedback, self-correction) | [...] | Agency | None; tools for humans | Implicit or basic | Explicit; operates with purpose, goals, and self-direction |\n| Context awareness | Low; stateless or snapshot-based | Moderate; some state tracking | High; uses memory, situational context, and environment models |\n| Infrastructure role | Embedded in apps or analytics pipelines | Middleware or service layer component | Composable agent mesh integrated with cloud, serverless, or edge systems | [...] | Characteristic | Traditional AI | Software agents | Agentic AI |\n ---  --- |\n|  | Spam filters, image classifiers, recommendation engines | Chatbots, task schedulers, monitoring agents | AI assistants, autonomous developer agents, multi-agent LLM orchestrations |\n| Execution model | Batch or synchronous | Event-driven or scheduled | Asynchronous, event-driven, and goal-driven |\n| Autonomy | Limited; often requires human or external orchestration | Medium; operates independently within predefined bounds | High; acts independently with adaptive strategies |\n| Reactivity | Reactive to input data | Reactive to environment and events | Reactive and proactive; anticipates and initiates actions |\n| Proactivity | Rare | Present in some systems | Core attribute; drives goal-directed behavior |",
      "score": 0.1788271,
      "raw_content": null

    {
      "url": "https://www.salesforce.com/customer-stories/bionic-james-lomas-byline/",
      "title": "The hard yards of enterprise AI: What it really takes to make ...",
      "content": "## 6. Use AI to elevate humans, not replace them.\n\nOne of the most exciting things we‚Äôre building with Agentforce is what we call the Wingman: an AI agent that sits alongside reps, offering real-time guidance, sentiment analysis, and quality assurance.\n\nThis isn‚Äôt about automation for its own sake. It‚Äôs about empowerment, giving all our reps a new superpower that enables them to have more powerful and higher converting conversations.\n\nIn the case of call quality, the impact is game-changing. Our Wingman shifts compliance from an opaque back-office activity and puts reps fully in control of their own call quality.\n\n## 7. Play the long game.\n\nEnterprise AI requires a leap of faith. [...] You can deliver AI quickly - often in days or weeks, but value doesn‚Äôt arrive on a fixed schedule. Spoiler alert: AI is not going to transform your business overnight!\n\nMany organizations assume AI agents will instantly improve as they‚Äôre exposed to internal data, but LLMs don‚Äôt automatically learn from your systems or customer interactions. They‚Äôre pre-trained, not self-updating.\n\nTo deliver reliable, high-quality responses, AI agents need an intentional cycle of continuous review and refinement. That means business teams regularly reviewing transcripts, updating instructions, tuning responses, and enriching the knowledge base over time.\n\nThis isn‚Äôt a sign that the technology is falling short. It is the work.\n\n## 6. Use AI to elevate humans, not replace them. [...] Whether the answer becomes bigger or smaller models, the organizations that will win aren‚Äôt the ones chasing the flashiest use cases. They‚Äôre the ones doing the hard yards: integrating AI deeply, refining it continuously, and staying focused on real business outcomes.\n\n> ### If you can‚Äôt tie AI initiatives directly to operational metrics, you‚Äôre probably still stuck in experimentation mode.\n>\n> James Lomas\n>\n> Chief Technology Officer, Bionic\n\n## Read the full story\n\nCustomer Story\n\n### Bionic boosts small business support with always-on help with Agentforce.\n\nAI agents handle first customer contact so reps have more time for 1:1 support.\n\nLearn more\n\n## Take the next step with Salesforce.\n\n### Get free CRM.",

Join us as we pursue our purpose to make the world work better for everyone.\n\n### Job Description [...] Export Control Regulations\n\nFor positions requiring access to controlled technology subject to export control regulations, including the U.S. Export Administration Regulations (EAR), ServiceNow may be required to obtain export control approval from government authorities for certain individuals. All employment is contingent upon ServiceNow obtaining any export license or other approval that may be required by relevant export control authorities.\n\nFrom Fortune. ¬©2025 Fortune Media IP Limited.       "content": "This strategic redesign is already taking shape across industries. At HPE, an enterprise software and services company, an AI agent called Alfred supports internal operational performance reviews. Toyota uses agentic tools to gain real-time visibility into vehicle arrivals at dealerships and is planning to empower agents to resolve supply chain issues - bypassing the need for human interaction with complex mainframe systems. These examples signal a shift away from traditional application modernization toward enabling agents to bridge legacy system gaps directly. [...] Enterprises are rapidly exploring agentic AI, with Gartner predicting that 15% of daily work decisions will be made autonomously by agentic AI by 2028, a significant increase from virtually none in 2024. Despite this momentum, many organizations face substantial hurdles in translating agentic pilots into production-ready solutions. Deloitte‚Äôs 2025 Emerging Technology Trends study indicates that only 14% of organizations have deployable solutions, and just 11% are actively using these systems in production. [...] The shift toward agentic AI represents more than a technological evolution; it is a fundamental organizational transformation that will reshape how enterprises operate, compete, and create value. Organizations that master agent-native process design, multi-agent orchestration, and silicon workforce management will be best positioned to thrive in an increasingly automated economy. Ultimately, success will depend on creating new forms of human - AI collaboration that capitalize on the complementary strengths of both human and silicon-based workers.\n\nTo explore how organizations can strategically embrace agentic AI and prepare for the future of work, read the full Deloitte Tech Trends report.\n\n### Contact\n\n#### Andrei Ionescu\n\nMarket Leader Consulting\n\naionescu@deloittece.com",

      "title": "The future of digital leadership",
      "content": "Collection\n\n### Resilience\n\nDeloitte partners with you to help your organisation meet today‚Äôs and future challenges and make resilience a driver of long‚Äëterm growth.\n\n### Work, reworked: What it takes to win in the age of Agentic AI\n\n### How to trust Generative AI and make it work for your organisation\n\nPerspective [...] ##### The autonomy-trust balance\n\nTo be trusted in the era of autonomous systems, with AI as a stepping stone, organisations, governments and public service need to repeatedly prove that digital systems are acting as intended. Autonomy without evidence invites regulatory action, customer defection, public backlash, or loss of stakeholder confidence. Trust without autonomy risks slowness and loss of competitive edge. And autonomy without human oversight invites loss of control. [...] ##### What digital leadership means\n\nDigital leadership is the capacity to turn digital capability into lasting value while taking responsibility for outcomes. It is not only about technology but about how people, processes, data and incentives are organised. It requires governance structures that enable safe experimentation, cultural practices that encourage transparency and accountability, and metrics that demonstrate trustworthiness over time.\n\nAn organisation's culture is pivotal to achieving the right balance between autonomy and trust: the norms, rituals and incentives inside an organisation will determine whether autonomous systems scale responsibly or degrade to become an uncontrollable risk.",

[...] ## Start small and define success clearly\n\nThe first question you need to answer isn‚Äôt ‚Äúwhat can this agent do?‚Äù but rather ‚Äúwhat problem are we solving?‚Äù Too many teams start by building an agent that tries to handle every possible scenario. This leads to complexity, slow iteration cycles, and agents that don‚Äôt excel at anything.\n\nInstead, work backwards from a specific use case. If you‚Äôre building a financial assistant, start with the three most common analyst tasks. If you‚Äôre building an HR helper, focus on the top five employee questions.       "url": "https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics-365/blog/it-professional/2026/02/04/ai-agent-performance-measurement/",
      "title": "AI Agent Performance Measurement: Redefining Excellence",
      "content": "Perhaps most critically, reasoning quality includes knowing what the agent doesn‚Äôt know. A well-designed agent admits uncertainty rather than fabricating answers. This is particularly challenging in the LLM where models are trained to produce answers no matter what. There are two parts to that problem, one the agent should reason and ask for additional data. In truly autonomous agents such interactions should go beyond slot filling or interview. It needs to be dynamic, adaptive, and contextual.  When the agent feels stuck, it should admit that and either ask for help from supervisor or simply escalate. In any case, responsible AI guardrails and validations are key to ensuring proper agent responses and guarded interactions. [...] ### Evaluating AI Agents in Contact Centers: Introducing the Multi-modal Agents Score\n\nA man wearing a headset smiling\n\n### Announcing General Availability of Proactive Voice Enhancements in Dynamics 365 Contact Center\n\n## Get started with Dynamics 365\n\nDrive more efficiency, reduce costs, and create a hyperconnected business that links people, data, and processes across your organization‚Äîenabling every team to quickly adapt and innovate.\n\nConnect with us on social [...] AI agents can learn from the best human agents and adapt their style in real time based on conversation context. A well-designed agent can operate in Controller mode for straightforward technical issues- direct and prescriptive-and shift to Empathizer mode when a customer shares difficult news. It adapts mid-conversation based on sentiment, issue complexity, and customer preferences.\n\nThis isn‚Äôt about mimicking personality types. It‚Äôs about dynamically deploying the right approach for each moment of each interaction. The best AI agents don‚Äôt choose between being helpful and being efficient. They recognize that true helpfulness often means being efficient. They adapt their communication style to what each customer needs in each moment.",
      "score": 0.10647691,
      "raw_content": null

      "url": "https://www.okta.com/blog/ai/ai-agent-authorization-gap/",
      "title": "AI Agent Security: The Authorization Gap in Shared ...",
      "content": "A CFO deploys an AI agent in a Slack channel. The agent authenticates with the CFO's credentials and inherits access to compensation data, board materials, and HR systems. A junior analyst asks: \"What's our Q3 compensation budget?\" The agent retrieves budget spreadsheets, compensation plans, and executive salary schedules. Authorization check: Can the CFO access these files? Yes. The agent responds to the channel. The junior analyst now knows the CEO's salary. So does everyone else in that channel.\n\nThe agent worked exactly as designed. The authorization model failed.\n\n## The Pattern: Four Platforms, One Common Thread [...] ### Products\n\nOur platforms secure all types of identity from AI agents to your customers, employees, and partners.\n\n#### Agentic AI Security\n\n#### Identity & Access Management\n\n#### Privileged Access Management\n\n#### Identity Threat Detection & Response\n\n#### Customer Identity & Access Management\n\n#### Identity Governance & Administration\n\n#### Integrations\n\n#### Platforms\n\n#### Okta\n\nSecure all of your identities within an identity security fabric.\n\n#### Auth0\n\nShip amazing experiences with enterprise-grade customer identity.\n\n### Solutions\n\nOkta is the neutral, powerful, and extensible platform that puts identity at the heart of your stack.\n\n#### By Identity Type\n\n#### By Industry\n\n#### Customer Success Stories\n\nBox enforces zero standing privileges with Okta Identity Governance.     {
      "url": "https://www.ibm.com/think/insights/accountability-gap-autonomous-ai",
      "title": "The accountability gap in autonomous AI",
      "content": "Agentic AI challenges all three of these assumptions. Autonomous agents are non-deterministic, operate at machine speed, and act continuously across APIs, tools and environments. In this model, identity is no longer stable human account or long-lived service principal. It can be ephemeral and purpose-built for a specific capability, workflow or even a single transaction, then revoked immediately after execution.\n\nAn end-to-end agentic flow has many agents logging in once, each running a discrete activitity. They don‚Äôt ‚Äúlog in‚Äù once. They might make thousands of decisions per hour, often on behalf of users, systems or other agents. They have an identity themselves and engage with each other in end-to-end transactional flows that span trust boundaries. [...] This issue isn‚Äôt a tooling gap; it‚Äôs a governance gap that must be closed.\n\n## The shift: From identity as access to identity as authority\n\nThe core mistake enterprises make is treating agent identity as a credential problem. Credentials are important, but in agentic systems they‚Äôre no longer a single login event that establishes trust for everything that follows.\n\nInstead, agents operate continuously, start multiple tools, cross systems, and take many independent actions over time. That means identity and authorization can‚Äôt be ‚Äúset once‚Äù at the start of a session; they must be validated and enforced throughout the workflow.\n\nAgentic AI requires a shift from access control to authority control. This means: [...] Unique agent identities with strong access management controls\n Designs that consider human and machine identities together\n Full end-to-end audit trails\n Clear processes around just-in-time and just-enough access with revocation\n\nAttackers are moving faster than defenders‚Äîtargeting AI agents precisely because they likely operate with accumulated privilege and low oversight.\n\nAgentic AI isn‚Äôt coming. It‚Äôs here. The question is no longer whether agents will execute business-critical actions‚Äîit‚Äôs whether enterprises can prove that those actions were authorized, scoped and accountable.",

      "raw_content": null

      "content": "This automation directly improves time to resolution and first-call resolution (an IT team‚Äôs ability to resolve a customer issue on the first call). This approach unlocks a new revenue path without standing up their own AI platform from scratch.\n\n## The architecture: A lakehouse and agentic layer built on watsonx\n\nCrushBank has built a hybrid, agentic architecture that treats enterprise data as the foundation of every AI workflow. [...] From a TCO perspective, this process means a CrushBank customer can:\n\n Reuse the same lakehouse, models and agents to solve multiple triage and routing problems.\n Avoid buying point solutions or licensing generic copilots per user when what they really need is domain-specific, multi-tenant AI wired into their core workflows.\n\n## Scaling with IBM: From IT tickets to an AI platform business\n\nCrushBank is now working with multiple partners who resell its platform, enabling MSPs and other providers to bring AI capabilities to hundreds of end customers without needing to build, secure and scale their own data and AI stacks.\n\nBecause the architecture is agentic, data-centric and embedded by design, scaling typically entails: [...] Full object storage\n\n The original documents are retained as full objects in Cloud Object Storage for traceability, auditability and direct retrieval when necessary.\n\nWatsonx.data and IBM Cloud provide CrushBank a single logical platform to query and combine structured and unstructured data.
